chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will compare the current long-term debt-to-equity ratio and the total debt-to-equity ratio of two companies from their previous long-term debt-to-equity ratios and total debt-to-equity ratios.

Debt-to-equity ratio refers to how much of the company's current assets are taken from debt compared to how much of the current assets are taken from equities. 

Long-term debt-to-equity ratio is the measure of how much of the company's asset is from their long-term debt and how much of the assets are from the company shareholder's equities. 

On the other hand, the total debt-to-equity ratio refers to the total debt compared to the total equity of the company.

In the problem, we have the given data for the two companies:

For American Airlines (AAL):

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term debt-to-equity ratio}&=490.66\\
\text{Total debt-to-equity ratio}&=531.61
\end{aligned}$$

For Pfizer (PFE):

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term debt-to-equity ratio}&=48.08\\
\text{Total debt-to-equity ratio}&=69.61
\end{aligned}$$

Based on the current data, here are the current values for each of the two companies:

For American Airlines (AAL):

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term debt-to-equity ratio}&=\text{No data}\\
\text{Total debt-to-equity ratio}&=-4.233
\end{aligned}$$

For Pfizer (PFE):

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Long-term debt-to-equity ratio}&=0.4253\\
\text{Total debt-to-equity ratio}&=1.22
\end{aligned}$$
As we can see, the ratios for both companies declined which indicates that a larger portion of their assets is now paid for by the company shareholders' equities rather than external debt.
